channel.title: Commandes on Gitctx Documentation
channel.description: Recent content in Commandes on Gitctx Documentation

item.description:
gitctx #

gitctx is a tool to manage git contexts

Synopsis #

gitctx helps you manage multiple git configurations and contexts easily. It allows you to switch between different git user profiles, repositories, and settings quickly.

If this is your first time using gitctx, you can initialize it with the ‘gitctx init’ command. It will set up the necessary configuration files and directories and store your current git configuration.

gitctx add #

A brief description of your command

Synopsis #

A longer description that spans multiple lines and likely contains examples and usage of using your command. For example:

Cobra is a CLI library for Go that empowers applications. This application is a tool to generate the needed files to quickly create a Cobra application.

gitctx add [flags]

Options # 

 -h, --help help for add

Options inherited from parent commands # 

 -v, --verbose Enable verbose output

SEE ALSO #

  • gitctx - gitctx is a tool to manage git contexts
Auto generated by spf13/cobra on 23-Aug-2025 #

gitctx init #

Initialize gitctx configuration folder and contexts

Synopsis #

This command initializes the gitctx configuration folder and contexts by searching for existing git configuration files in common locations:

Here are the common locations:

  • ~/.gitconfig
  • ~/.config/git/config

Here are some examples of how to use the init command:

  • gitctx init
  • gitctx init –no-fetch-context (to skip fetching contexts from git config files)
gitctx init [flags]

Options # 

 -h, --help help for init
 -n, --no-fetch-context Skip fetching contexts from git config files

Options inherited from parent commands # 

 -v, --verbose Enable verbose output

SEE ALSO #

  • gitctx - gitctx is a tool to manage git contexts
Auto generated by spf13/cobra on 23-Aug-2025 #

gitctx list #

List all available gitctx contexts

Synopsis #

This command lists all available gitctx contexts that have been created. It helps you see which git configurations are available for switching.

You can use this command :

  • gitctx list The current context will be marked with an asterisk (*)
gitctx list [flags]

Options # 

 -h, --help help for list

Options inherited from parent commands # 

 -v, --verbose Enable verbose output

SEE ALSO #

  • gitctx - gitctx is a tool to manage git contexts
Auto generated by spf13/cobra on 23-Aug-2025 #

gitctx version #

Return your gitctx version and architecture

Synopsis #

This command return your current gitctx version, operating system, and architecture. It is useful to check if you are using the correct version of gitctx for your system.

Here are tge commands to catch the version and architecture: For version : gitctx version -q' For operating system : gitctx version | awk ‘{print $4}’ | cut -d/ -f1 For architecture : gitctx version | awk ‘{print $4}’ | cut -d/ -f2
